title: Travel Survival Phrases
objectives: Master essential phrases for traveling in Korea
Practice asking for help in various situations
Build confidence for real-world Korean interactions
context: Congratulations! You've learned the fundamentals of Korean - from Hangul alphabet to basic grammar. This final lesson brings it all together with practical survival phrases you'll use constantly when traveling in Korea or interacting with Korean speakers.

Did you know? Korea is an incredibly safe and tourist-friendly country. Most Koreans are very patient with learners and appreciate any effort to speak Korean, even just a few phrases. Don't be afraid to make mistakes - your effort will be warmly received!

This lesson covers essential travel scenarios: shopping, asking for help, dealing with emergencies, and polite requests. These phrases will help you navigate markets, stores, hotels, and unexpected situations with confidence.

By the end of this lesson, you'll have a complete beginner's toolkit for Korean communication! You'll know how to read, introduce yourself, order food, get around, and handle common travel situations. You're ready to start your Korean adventure!

sentences.english: Can I use a card? / Do you accept cards?
Please say it again / Please say it one more time
Can you give a discount? / Is there a discount?

explanation: 얼마예요? (How Much?): Essential shopping phrase! 얼마 = how much. Add 예요 to make it polite. Always use this when asking prices. 이거 얼마예요? (How much is this?), 저거 얼마예요? (How much is that?).
돼요? (Is it okay?): From 되다 (to become/work). Used to ask if something is possible or acceptable. 카드 돼요? (Is card okay?), 사진 돼요? (Is photo okay?), 여기 돼요? (Is here okay?). Very versatile!
주세요 Requests: [Action] + 주세요 = please do [action] for me. Examples: 도와주세요 (please help), 말해 주세요 (please speak), 기다려 주세요 (please wait). The -아/어 주세요 pattern shows someone doing something FOR you.
천천히 & 다시: 천천히 (slowly) + 말해 주세요 (please speak) = please speak slowly. 다시 (again) + 말해 주세요 = please speak again. Add 한 번 (one time) = 다시 한 번 = once more. Perfect for when you don't understand!
Language Questions: [Language] + 하세요? = Do you speak [language]? Examples: 영어 하세요? (Do you speak English?), 한국어 하세요? (Do you speak Korean?), 중국어 하세요? (Do you speak Chinese?).
잃어버리다 (To Lose): Verb for losing things. 잃어버렸어요 = I lost it (past tense). Examples: 지갑을 잃어버렸어요 (I lost my wallet), 핸드폰을 잃어버렸어요 (I lost my phone). Hope you never need this!
찾다 vs 찾고 있다: 찾다 = to find/look for. 찾고 있어요 = I am looking for (present continuous). Use -고 있다 to show ongoing action. 화장실을 찾고 있어요 (I'm looking for the bathroom).
Korean Won: Korean currency is 원 (won). Prices use Sino-Korean numbers: 천 원 (1,000 won), 만 원 (10,000 won). 만 (10,000) is an important unit! 1,000,000 won = 백만 원 or 100 만원.

Cultural Tips: Koreans appreciate ANY attempt to speak Korean, even if you make mistakes! Always bow slightly when greeting or thanking. Use two hands when giving/receiving money or cards. In stores, items are often placed in trays rather than handed directly - it's polite custom, not impersonal!
Emergency Phrases: 도와주세요 (help!), 119 (ambulance/fire), 112 (police). Korean emergency services are excellent! Most major cities have English-speaking operators. Stay calm and speak clearly.
